title: Hello, I'm wondering if I can omit a cosigned PERSONAL student loan from my chapter 7 bankruptcy case?
question: I am thinking about filing for Ch. 7 bankruptcy, no asset. I have all my paperwork ready to go but I have 2 loans that are cosigned by my uncle that I would like to leave off and continue paying. I know that student loans will not come off anyway so should I leave it on there or leave it off? Does it matter b/c student loans aren't affected by bankruptcy? The 2 loans were through fafsa but was not provided by the government, it had to be a personal loan that was cosigned however the loan clearly states that it was a student loan. The loan was then split into 2, one half going to Citibank N.A. and their student loan department, now transferred to FirstMarkServices and the other to Discover Student Loans.
answers: You are signing under penalty of perjury that you are listing ALL your debts. The penalty is $500,000 or five years in jail. You might not get caught. is the risk worth it to you? There is no benefit to not listing, since you are going to keep paying anyway.
List it. All creditors must be listed. In most cases, student loans are nondischargeable. And because loans are cosigned, you can continue to make payments.

The bankruptcy paperwork requires you to list all creditors you owe money to so you should list it. You are signing your paperwork under penalty of perjury that you have listed all your debts and assets so you should not intentionally leave a creditor off of your paperwork. You can continue paying the personal student loan.
